Do you have to use a terminal for C++?
No
If you've heard of xcode, you can write c++ in xcode
and thats a nice editor thats for OSX
If you've heard of Microsoft Visual Studio thats another IDE for C++
That doesn't use the terminal at all
So you can definitely write C++ without using...
without being on a Linux terminal.
In this course we will do everything in the Linux terminal however.
Just because its easier to have a single environment for everything
And be able to teach you using one set of tools.
That being said you will have some success...
You should have some success running the assignments on a OSX based computer
If you have xcode in the command line of
Windows users... your best bet is to use either the
remote EWS machines
So SSH in using puddy or using FastX
If you go on the EngineeringIT website you should be able to find pointers for those.

This was an interesting question.
This is a question about "auto"
So figuring out...
So remember auto is that keyword that you used if you don't want to write your type
and you want C++ to kind of figure out what the type of the right hand side expression is
And so somebody asked a question:
What if I have int m int n and then auto x = n / m?
I'm dividing two integers
Does C++ know to make that auto variable be a double?
No
Unfortunately not.
In general if you're dividing two integers you're always gonna get back an integer.
So if you wanted to make sure that you're getting a double you would have to explicitly cast one of the integer arguments into a double
Or assign it into a temporary double and then use that as part of the calculation
But thats a good question because that maybe is not obvious what happens if you're dividing two integers and you use [auto]
[nothing]
Its actually true even if you said double double double k = n / m
where n and m are integers
Its still going to give you an integer value and then assign the integer to value into a double
So not actually going to give floating point value
[nothing]
In the video it said that after you compile
object files using -c so you have clang++
std = whatever
stdlib = whatever
-c name of file
We output object files
And then you said that we needed to fill in blanks.
When does the filling in the blanks happen?
Thats the linking step.
Compiling with -c makes your object files
The object files are sort of incomplete.
They are machine level instructions but they are missing some parts.
The linking step is what links everything together
and sort of fills in okay...
I actually know where that lives now
Its over at this part of the binary
and I know where that lives. Its over there.
It ties everything back together so that you actually have the full complete program.
The linking step is that.
You may have a compiler error when making an object file.
Or you might have a compiler error when you're linking.
There are compiler errors when you're making the actual
machine code for functions or for a class when we get to classes.
Or linking errors when it can't fill in the gaps.
If maybe you declared a function and then never defined it.
So then it would be a linking error because it knows
You've promised me that there's gonna be this function with this signature.. somewhere.
And then failed to tell me where.
So that would be a linking error.
So its sort of
Even within compilation there's kind of two steps
There's this generating the code and then there's this linking.
